Definition: Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by overwhelming daytime drowsiness and sudden sleep attacks.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic factors and brain chemistry.
Symptoms: Daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, sleep paralysis, and hallucinations.
Treatment: Medications to manage symptoms and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Nasal polyps are soft, painless, noncancerous growths on the lining of the nasal passages or sinuses.
Symptoms: Nasal congestion, loss of smell, and sinus infections.
Treatment: Medications such as corticosteroids and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: Nasopharyngeal cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the nasopharynx, the area behind the nose and above the back of the throat.
Causes: Infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Nasal congestion, ear problems, and neck lumps.

Definition: Nausea is the sensation of an urge to vomit, while vomiting is the forceful expulsion of stomach contents.
Causes: Infections, motion sickness, medications, and gastrointestinal disorders.
Symptoms: Feeling sick, abdominal discomfort, and retching.
Treatment: Medications to control nausea and vomiting, and addressing underlying causes.

Definition: Neck pain is discomfort in the neck area, which can be acute or chronic.
Causes: Injuries, poor posture, and degenerative diseases.
Symptoms: Pain, stiffness, and reduced range of motion.
Treatment: Pain management, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney disorder characterized by excessive protein loss in the urine.
Causes: Diabetes, minimal change disease, and infections.
Diagnosis: Urine tests, blood tests, and kidney biopsy.
Treatment: Medications, dietary changes, and management of underlying conditions.

Definition: Nerve root pain is pain that occurs when a nerve root in the spine is compressed or irritated.
Causes: Herniated discs, spinal stenosis, and injuries.
Symptoms: Sharp pain, numbness, and weakness in the affected area.
Treatment: Pain management, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Neuroendocrine tumors are a diverse group of tumors that arise from neuroendocrine cells.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Varies widely depending on the tumor location; may include flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, blood tests, and biopsy.

Definition: Neurofibromatosis type 1 is a genetic disorder that causes tumors to grow on nerves.
Causes: Genetic mutations in the NF1 gene.
Symptoms: Caf√©-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and learning disabilities.
Treatment: Management of symptoms and monitoring for complications.

Definition: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder is an autoimmune condition that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord.
Causes: Autoimmune response against aquaporin-4 water channels.
Symptoms: Vision loss, weakness, and sensory disturbances.
Diagnosis: MRI, blood tests, and clinical evaluation.

Definition: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is a condition characterized by excess fat accumulation in the liver without alcohol consumption.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, but may include fatigue and discomfort in the upper right abdomen.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies and liver function tests.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, weight loss, and management of underlying conditions.

Definition: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a group of blood cancers that includes any lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes, fever, weight loss, and night sweats.
Diagnosis: Biopsy, imaging studies, and blood tests.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapy.

Definition: Non-small cell lung cancer is the most common type of lung cancer, accounting for about 85% of cases.
Causes: Smoking, exposure to secondhand smoke, and environmental toxins.
Symptoms: Cough, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, biopsy, and pulmonary function tests.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapy.
